title: Auditory Cortex Involvement: Left Temporal Lobectomy
chief_complaint: The patient reports difficulty following verbal directions despite having no history of audiologic or otologic problems.

problem_summary.onset: Seizure disorder began at age 3; auditory processing difficulties noted in adulthood.
problem_summary.course: Frequent and recurrent seizures (2-3 per day) despite medication. Underwent left temporal lobectomy.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral auditory processing deficits pre-operatively; Left hemisphere seizure focus.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Generalized seizure disorder, clonic activity of the right arm, 'drop' attacks.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Unable to maintain employment as a medical assistant/dental technician due to seizure frequency.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Control of seizures to allow for employment and improved quality of life.

history.present_illness: Patient has a long-standing history of generalized seizure disorder originating from the left anterior temporal lobe. She reports difficulty following verbal directions.
history.otologic_history: Negative for audiologic or otologic problems.
history.medical_psych_history: Generalized seizure disorder since age 3. EEG showed focal slowing in left anterior temporal lobe spreading to other regions. Intelligence testing placed her in the low average range.
history.prior_management: Various medications prescribed to lessen severity but failed to adequately control seizures.
history.patient_goals: Surgical candidacy evaluation for left temporal lobectomy.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Pure tone thresholds were bilaterally normal.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Dichotic digits test performance was severely depressed in both ears.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Late potentials and P300s (C3 and C4 recording sites). No repeatable responses were discernible for any of the various presentations.

history.present_illness: Follow-up 1 week after left frontotemporal craniotomy/lobectomy.
history.otologic_history: Resection extended from temporal pole 3 cm in superior temporal gyrus, 4.5 cm in medial temporal gyrus, and 5 cm in inferior temporal gyrus.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Pure tone thresholds remained bilaterally normal.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Dichotic digits test performance improved dramatically to almost normal bilaterally.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Late potentials (Left Ear Stim): Small but repeatable N1 and P2 responses identified at C3 and C4. Large but delayed P300 response noted.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Late potentials (Right Ear Stim): Not as clearly defined. Definite P2 and possible shallow N1 (80-160 msec). Noisy, broad peaked P300 (questionable presence).

overall_audiologic_summary: This case involves a 20-year-old female with a severe seizure disorder originating in the left anterior temporal lobe. Pre-operative testing revealed normal peripheral hearing but severe central deficits, manifested as bilaterally depressed dichotic digits scores (15% LE, 25% RE) and absent late auditory evoked potentials. Following a left temporal lobectomy, the patient showed dramatic improvement in auditory processing. Post-operative dichotic digits scores returned to near normal (85% LE, 88% RE), and late potentials (N1, P2, P300) became identifiable, particularly with left ear stimulation. The right ear stimulation (contralateral to the lesion) yielded poorer morphologic responses, suggesting a contralateral ear effect or reduced volume conduction.
counseling_points: Explain that the pre-operative difficulty with verbal directions was likely due to the 'interference' caused by the seizure activity in the auditory areas of the brain.
Highlight the significant improvement in processing speech (dichotic digits) following the surgery.
Discuss that while behavioral scores improved, some electrophysiological responses (especially from the right ear) remain abnormal, reflecting the surgical removal of temporal lobe tissue.
Monitor for any changes in communication ability as the brain continues to heal.
notes_for_actor: Patient is a young adult (20) who has dealt with seizures her whole life.
She is likely relieved post-surgery as seizures have decreased and she can return to work.
She is cooperative but may have had difficulty with complex tasks (like counting rare stimuli for P300) prior to surgery.
